Patch Set 1: Verified+1

Build Successful 

https://jenkins.openbmc.org/job/ci-repository/3727/ : SUCCESS

Patch Set 1:

@jmbills.  Can you take a look at the comment in the commit message, and log_services.hpp.  Do you know why it was done that way?
Assignee added: Jason Bills <jason.m.bills@linux.intel.com>

Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1

(1 comment)

> Patch Set 1:
> 
> @jmbills.  Can you take a look at the comment in the commit message, and log_services.hpp.  Do you know why it was done that way?

I believe some web searches showed that this approach was the "fastest" way to read data from a file.  The end result we care about is that the contents of the file can be downloaded by a user, so as long as that works, we're good.

Patch Set 39:

(1 comment)
Change has been successfully rebased and submitted as 27b0cf90f6cba207837f5c263a45c6ea5651975b

I think we used this because it was shown in some comparisons as the "fast" way to read data from a large file.  It was assigned to res.body() to try to avoid a copy.  If res.openFile() allows a user to download the file contents, that is all we need.

coolio.  I was hoping it was something like that.

Yes, res.openFile() should be functionally much faster, as it skips the string step entirely, and goes directly from filesystem->socket.  Also, it's been optimized by people that understand network IO better than we do, so it should be more efficient.

I'll get the comment and TODO removed.
Done

Some of the changes in this file are not related to file body implementation.
Correct me if I am wrong. Since this file is diverged a lot from what we have now in master , do you still think we should work on top of this patch set?
This has been corrected.  YOu're right, this had a number of merge conflicts, becuase previously nobody was looking at it.  It has been cleaned up.

does this compile? re-assingment to reference?
Even if it worked, shouldn't we keep already assigned headers to newly created stringbody? 
Use Case. 
Current body is filebody. User has assigned some headers already to the current body. 
User decided to change the body type to stringbody by calling body(). 
Now user has lost all already set headers. 
The use case is applicable for stringbody to filebody transition as well.
So the question is shouldn't we copy all already set headers to the new response?
Exception  is for headers such as content type and length, which we need to be reset for new body type.
I think assignment operator is invoked on a possible dangling reference in case of header above.
I believe this is corrected now.

clear means only clear he body or all content including header?
Should we reset to monostate ?
The intent of this was to reset back to the initial state, which is stringBody.
Done
overwriting existing headers.
Yep, you're right.  I think this is fixed.
why non-standard type, if one exists in standard? don't you think it will add to the cognitive burden?
Because the one in the standard has the problem that you found of throwing exceptions.  This is documented in a comment below.
Ack
can't you move all variable to same place? now we have to scroll up and down to see all memeber variables.
At the moment, public variables are at the top, and private variables are at the bottom.  While I agree, keeping them all in one place would likely be better, that would be part of another patch.
Done.  Leaving for another patch.

how are we going to handle a response that currently holds a filebody in variant?

over-all this code does not make use of re-usablity comes from member object's move implementation. we could have simply used std::move(stringResponse). I am not sure what is the benefit we get here.

> how are we going to handle a response that currently holds a filebody in variant?

At the moment it doesn't.  This line will need to be replaced with a visitor.

> 
> over-all this code does not make use of re-usablity comes from member object's move implementation. we could have simply used std::move(stringResponse). I am not sure what is the benefit we get here.

You're right, we could've used std::move.
I used std::move in one spot.  Please point out others.
Done.  If you see any that I missed, please point them out.
it seems you used boost::variant just because of this no-throw visit. If that is the reason we could still go for std::variant and use if-else block as you preferred everywhere else
Lets try both options and see which code is more readable.
Done.  variant2 is what we decided on.
why you need this temporary?

Because you can't move out of and into the same object at once.

If there's a better way to write this code, I'm happy to try, but I'm not sure how.
Done.  Explained in other comment.

why adding another ref variable, while we already have an object in the variant to give access to the data? Don't you think it as extra burden to manage it to point to the right object? you can modify fields() function to return proper base reference based on active index.

> why adding another ref variable, while we already have an object in the variant to give access to the data?

Because visit is more expensive of an operation than one would think, so reducing the number of times we have to call visit seems like a good thing.

> Don't you think it as extra burden to manage it to point to the right object? you can modify fields() function to return proper base reference based on active index.

Let me try that and see if the code gets worse.  When I first wrote this, I didn't have a fields() method.
I tried what you suggested.  Please take a look.
Ack

Most of the comments seem to be about needing null checks, which, it's not clear how to add in all cases, because that would introduce a failure path that's not possible, but would need to be modeled in all the APIs.

Which pattern do you think is better, pointers, or visit?
Please also review the prior patch: https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/bmcweb/+/65645
I agree with the use of visit

why no null check here? 
and what is the strategy if both are null?

1)can we assume that at least one is true? will clang-tidy pass ?
2) can  we create one new string_response ?

> why no null check here? 

Because it's not possible.

> and what is the strategy if both are null?

When/how could that happen?

> 
> 1)can we assume that at least one is true? will clang-tidy pass ?

The build passes, so yes, tidy passes.

> 2) can  we create one new string_response ?

I don't understand what you're suggesting.

When/how could that happen?
The fundamental problem here is ,technically a variant can hold non of the alternatives. A default constructed variant could be  assigned to the string response variable, if we are not careful. 

You seems to have issue in using a throwing function ,even though we know that it will never throw. But you are happy to ignore the needed null checks if we use get_if. 
In a way the argument is "i am not okay with a terminate due to exception, but ok with a crash due to null pointer access".  
If we are not giving a complete solution , then get_if or boost:variant will not do anything better. 

I added the null check comment everywhere just to put those places in your notice

I don't understand what you're suggesting.
 I was asking if we can create a new string response in case of non of the alternatives are held by variant.

> When/how could that happen?
> The fundamental problem here is ,technically a variant can hold non of the alternatives.

variant2 cannot.  it will always hold one of the alteratives.

> A default constructed variant could be  assigned to the string response variable, if we are not careful. 
> 

The variant default constructs to the first item in the list.  This is true of both std::variant and boost::variant2

> You seems to have issue in using a throwing function ,even though we know that it will never throw. But you are happy to ignore the needed null checks if we use get_if.

We have tidy checks that have issues with throwing functions.  If a function throws, it will crash all of bmcweb.  Considering everything in the Response object is a handlable error, we can't really throw exceptions.

> In a way the argument is "i am not okay with a terminate due to exception, but ok with a crash due to null pointer access".  

This is not the argument.  The argument here is that this code iterates all the possible values.  If you prefer, I can move it back to variant::visit, which would require neither exceptions nor pointer dereferences.

> If we are not giving a complete solution , then get_if or boost:variant will not do anything better. 
> 
> I added the null check comment everywhere just to put those places in your notice

You asked for null checks, but you didnt' suggest what you wanted to do if that pointer is null.  for things returning a reference, would you like us to convert back to string_resposne?  If so, that's doable.
In variant2 there's no possibility for none of the alternatives to be held by the variant.  It is one or the other, there is no valueless_by_exception.

I am ok with the current change as long as the variant always holds one of the alternatives. I added this comment because you said before "get api will throw so don't use it". I thought you wanted to handle the impossible scenario of returning the null as well.

Personally, I favour generic visit to the if-else chain. Given the fact that visit no more throws, I like to see single liner visit in the code. You can ignore it if you prefer otherwise

> I am ok with the current change as long as the variant always holds one of the alternatives. I added this comment because you said before "get api will throw so don't use it".

std::get can throw an exception, std::get_if cannot.

> I thought you wanted to handle the impossible scenario of returning the null as well.

I'm fine with handling it, I'm just not sure how in this case.

> 
> Personally, I favour generic visit to the if-else chain. Given the fact that visit no more throws, I like to see single liner visit in the code. You can ignore it if you prefer otherwise

ACK.  I can move the code back to the visitor pattern.  Thank you for your input.  It might work now because of variant2 having a double copy implementation, but it's still undefined behavior.
Ack
Code moved back to visitor.
why no null check here?

Same as above.  Not possible.

The only alternative would be visit, which we could do, but I wanted to look at the pointer option.
Done
When changed to std::variant, this operation seems to throw, which isn't great.

True that is the reason I invented safemove wrapper. I don't know how we can avoid it. The root cause seems to be from file body move. We should wrap this code around try-catch irrespective of what move assignment we use(individual alternatives move  or variant move)

> True that is the reason I invented safemove wrapper. I don't know how we can avoid it.

I would much rather we rely on variant2, which is documented, than a method we created ourselves.

> The root cause seems to be from file body move. We should wrap this code around try-catch irrespective of what move assignment we use(individual alternatives move  or variant move)

As-written, this doesn't throw on a move.  Why would we add a try-catch?
I miss-read your comment. I thought you were planning to replace the variant move to individual alternatives move. I did not notice that you were commenting about "why not going with std::variant"
ACK
it could be neither, valueless by exception is not possible in boost variant?

> valueless by exception is not possible in boost variant

Correct.  This is an important difference in the design of variant2.
But how does boost variant handle non of alternatives case? Is there any compile time check to avoid such scenrio. Like disabling of default constructor?

> But how does boost variant handle non of alternatives case?

Non alternatives is not possible.  It will always be one of the template params.

> Is there any compile time check to avoid such scenrio. Like disabling of default constructor?

I'm not sure what you're asking, but I'm guessing that it's answered by the variant2 documentation:
https://www.boost.org/doc/libs/1_80_0/libs/variant2/doc/html/variant2.html
Ack

Don't you think that this will increase size of change-set? This is a backward compatibility issue in the usage of body(). Some one might have used the pattern body() +="****" in their code. 
Now we must add another "if" check everywhere body() has been used. 
My Suggestion would be to use the intent of the user here. 
If he calls body() then he wanted to use string body as response. Then it is better to move to string-body if the current alternative is not that. So create string-body and return the reference to it.

> Don't you think that this will increase size of change-set?

Yes, but there's not that many calls to body().

> This is a backward compatibility issue in the usage of body().
> Some one might have used the pattern body() +="****" in their code. 

I'm assuming you mean downstream code?  That's not something we optimize for.  People can write whatever they want, including making this same change.  If we have to optimize for everyones downstream API changes, we can never change any internal method call, which isn't really doable.

> Now we must add another "if" check everywhere body() has been used. 

Correct, because now Response might not be of type string.

> My Suggestion would be to use the intent of the user here. 
> If he calls body() then he wanted to use string body as response. Then it is better to move to string-body if the current alternative is not that. So create string-body and return the reference to it.

There are cases where that's not true, but I can give it a shot.
Does this work for you?

Yes. As you have already made changes in calling sites, I don't see any issue.
But as an API, returning nullptr is an error-prone one. It is easy to forget the null check before use by the caller. If mandatory null check is the expectation here, then I am ok with that too.
Mandatory null check is required, but I'm open to other options.

> 
> technically we can call a single move at the emplace argument itself right?

We can't, because you will then be reading values from a moved object.

> I meant that when I said no need for temp object. 
> But not sure if moving just the sliced part(base) of an object like this is a good idea or not.

Can you give me the exact code you think we should use here that you think handles dangling reference problems?  I'm a little confused at your response.

> But you already moved it in line 401

Right, but it's a matter of order.

> 
> Can you give me the exact code you think...
> 
> if (!std::holds_alternative<file_response>(response))
> {
>    response.emplace<file_response>(std::move(fields()));
>  }

The code above has a dangling reference problem.
fields() returns a reference to to the response object.
std::move turns that into an rvalue reference, still pointing at response.
response.emplace destroys the value, thus invalidating the reference.
file_response constructor is now run on a dangling reference, leading to use after free issues.

> 
>             
> this is exactly what I did in a generic manner in this patch set 
> https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/bmcweb/+/65054

When I tried this in the past, there were use after free errors due to undefined behavior.

I was speculating that before destroying the old object new object would have already constructed. 
I am not sure how boost::variant2 ensures thread safety when new object's constructor throws in this case.
This solves the problem I was facing in emplace. Thanks for pointing that out.

> I was speculating that before destroying the old object new object would have already constructed. 

Because the two objects share the same memory, that's not possible.

> I am not sure how boost::variant2 ensures thread safety when new object's constructor throws in this case.

bmcweb only has one thread, thread safety doesn't apply here.

> This solves the problem I was facing in emplace. Thanks for pointing that out.

bmcweb only has one thread, thread safety doesn't apply here.

sorry for the typo. I meant "exception safety" not "thread safety"
I thought boost::variatn will put back old object if new object constructor fails. But here it seems it already destructed the old object before creating new one.
Since we are letting the process to terminated on oom exception, and that is the only exception that can occur, the safety does not matter much for this code

I was testing the change set with large size file. The socket is getting closed after some time before the completion of the filetransfer. Perhaps this deadline timer is the reason. What is the plan for the timers to make large-size file transfer working?

I have no plan for supporting large files, nor does this patchset support them.  This commit was just about efficiency and avoiding a file copy.  If you have plans, feel free to push code for it.

Keep in mind, the http timers have pretty significant security requirements, so please make sure all the denial of service vectors are addressed by whatever you design.
This is no different than what we had before right? So outside the scope of this commit.

Correct.  The only change is that now bmcweb won't crash if you try to source a file larger than ram.  I'm happy to discuss changing the timers (for the 15th time.... ug) to make that use case more valuable, but in the context of this commit, I don't think we need to.

>  but in the context of this commit, I don't think we need to.

Agreed.
I agree with the scope of this commit. Timer issue to help dump offload can be implemented in a different commit.
